discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Should we raise the ETH debt ceiling?

content.content: We are getting close to the ETH debt ceiling again (154 mil / 160 mil as of this writing). Given the uncertainty around the Dai peg, the community may want to consider raising the debt ceiling again. Please weigh in on what you feel is right given the current environment. The results of the poll will be included either in Friday’s executive or as part of an expedited executive vote if necessary. What should the new ETH debt ceiling be?     160 million (NO CHANGE) 170 million 175 million 180 million 185 million Abstain / Show results     0 voters     EDIT / SUMMARY: 180 million was the winning poll option, and as a result has been placed in today’s Executive Vote.

I also think that an ETH B vault should be created with a higher stability fee and lower liquidation ratio that would provide excess liquidity during times it is needed.  Perhaps a ceiling of 25-50 Million is appropriate for the debt ceiling on ETH B stability fee 20%?

FourthStreet:  ETH B stability fee 20%   No-one will touch this at that rate.  I don’t care what the LR is. I do like the idea of having multiple facilities for collateral with increasing fees though since as one fills up we can see if they will take any on the next with the higher fee.  It would help us decide what is the optimal fee to either generate more use or reduce it on each collateral type.
We’re still seeing strong demand for the ETH-A Vault, seems like a good idea to raise the debt ceiling for that. And to keep the 0% RP considering the current situation.

I disagree.  If the choice is get liquidated, pay $1.15 for Dai to try and close out debt from your vault, or mint Dai at 20% stability fee for ETH until the system settles down you will definitely be minting Dai using the ETH B vault.  This takes place in cases where “ETH A” is at the debt ceiling.  It is simply available to provide liquidity during emergencies.
We should start the ETH B vault.
We should lower the LR for ETH-A to 101% and set its DC to 300M.
well, if anything that would be a great way to test the Keeper system

https://vote.makerdao.com/executive-proposal/raise-the-etha-debt-ceiling-to-180m   Any technical reason why the description is   Raise the ETH-A Debt Ceiling 20M to a new limit of 180M   and not   Raise the ETH-A Debt Ceiling 160M to a new limit of 180M   Simple typo or more complicated reason ?
Because its saying that we’re raising the limit by 20M to 180M.

MakerMan:  It would help us decide what is the optimal fee to either generate more use or reduce it on each collateral type.   @MakerMan I would love to hear your thoughts very specifically on this point. Can you elaborate a little further on what definition of optimal you are looking for in here?
Can we have a new vote, please? We are at 92% utilization. This is getting absurd - can’t we set a higher ETH DC (300M, 400M) so that we don’t waste gas every few days?

We really need to start collecting some fees, we are clearly unsustainable atm. Buffer at 260k is laughable. Even if there is no consensus for ETH-A (i would go with 0.25p), we could increase it for BAT and WBTC.
Although I agree I don’t think it will have a significant impact if we exclude ETH, perhaps once we apply the PSM assuming it’s a success we can increase the base rate 0,25%

discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Should we increase USDC-A debt ceiling?

content.content: Vault type USDC-A debt ceiling has only 4m DAI buffer left due to some increased minting from arbitrageurs in the last few days (about 20m increase since Monday). DAI is also trending higher and currently stands at $1.03. Fortunately we have USDT and PAX Vault available and ideally we would like to see some diversification from USDC into other stablecoins. However those two Vault types are not efficient in terms of capital use (higher liquidation ratio for both) and we are still testing how appealing they are for arbitrageurs as they just got launched. There is also an additional buffer available in USDC-B Vault, but this type of vault is primarily better suited for auctions due to high SF. Also, if we are afraid DAI/USDC arbitrageurs won’t be available to mint any more DAI from USDC and peg might be affected negatively, there is still a lot of DAI liquidity on Compound and arbitrageurs could still borrow there. But obviously we want arbitrageurs to use Maker and we know Maker is more popular because it has liquidations turned off and USDC price is fixed. So by being more conservative I think we should be increasing USDC-A debt ceiling very soon, the question is by how much. If the outcome of this vote is to increase it, the vote will go straight into executive this Friday.     Increase USDC-A Debt Ceiling by 20m DAI Increase USDC-A Debt Ceiling by 40m DAI Increase USDC-A Debt Ceiling by 60m DAI Keep USDC-A Debt ceiling at 40m DAI Abstain     0 voters     This poll closes in 24 hours.

discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Should we raise WBTC Debt Ceiling?

content.content: Overview With WBTC reaching a new high of ~11k WBTC minted is it time to again consider raising the debt ceiling? We’ve so far seen fairly significant demand for WBTC loans. Currently, it backs about 10% of all dai minted.   twitter.com    BitGo (BitGo)  Today we surpassed 10,000 WBTCs minted!  This is a great milestone for #BTC  on #Ethereum. BitGo is proud to be in this unique position to provide this service for #DeFi. https://t.co/dqdniuv7LQ   10:07 PM - 6 Jul 2020     18          3            You can find a brief overview of some of the risk considerations to be made around this collateral in this thread At a high level the pros are:  Increase the ability to provide long leverage for one of the most in-demand assets in the portfolio. Potential increase to overall DAI supply Potential increase for protocol revenue from the non-zero SF  Cons:  Increases exposure to WBTC custodial risk Increases exposure to BTC volatility   Ceiling adjustment Here are a few polling options that approximately spaced around $13.75 MM apart (so I can have 5 options) with the top option being about 75% of the current WBTC supply     20MM (no change) 34MM 48MM 61MM 75MM Let the risk team decide Abstain     0 voters      Risk Premium Adjustment     1% 2% (no change) 3% 4% 5% Let the risk team decide abstain     0 voters      Next steps Poll will run for one week and depending on the result will move on-chain assuming the outcome of the poll deems it necessary
I do feel like the increasing the debt ceiling will suck more WBTC into existence.  I’d like to see what the risk team thinks.  Maybe we are waiting for ren-BTC and tBTC?

Going to plug the Practical Guide to the Signaling Process again. If you want to run some informal polls, then this doesn’t have to be a signal request. If it is a signal request though, please do your best to cover the ‘must-haves’ in that list (and give due consideration to the ‘should haves.’)

I’ve been campaigning over there as well. [renBTC] MIP6 Collateral Application, but the one thing to consider on that front is the timelines. With the current timelines / mips process I think it is safe to say that renBTC is at least 4 weeks out. tBTC who knows. That project is in a pretty odd state ATM.

I’m against raising the DC for any coin except ETH because I don’t see any improvements after repeteadly doing so. People just stop buying DAI after it reaches 2% (next time maybe 3%…). I don’t think we should allow DAI to be backed 50%+ (even 20% is too much for me) with wBTC+USDC+USDT…).

Personally I would like to see a co-ordinated effort to get another 50M DAI of liquidity out there.   Really as an experiment to see if it would even put a decent dent in the PEG (1.014 to perhaps 1.005) - which at this time I think is less rather than more likely but it would be an interesting test. USDC-A SF down from 4-3 (maybe 2 even)% leave DC for now until it gets soaked up. WBTC SF down from 2-1.5% up DC at least 10M - maybe 20M PSM of 20M but I’d like to see a PSM that would control rate of use by having a variable pricing band that changes based on how much stablecoin is in the facility.   Still working up what I consider best case PSM design. I think LINK is risky to add but think it could also mint 10M DAI if the LR is reasonable (150-170), SF of perhaps 2%. I am also interested in Lev’s MIP20 approach but don’t think it has enough teeth for what we lose.  If we are going to give up on the 1:1 DAI backing I’d rather do it in a way that has significant teeth and in two steps.  Threaten to do it (via a MIP proposal) then if the markets don’t flinch actually Mint 1% new DAI from thin air, run with a negative surplus.   If the markets still don’t flinch then buy assets with the funds and keep them outside of the system.    But I think a real discussion on ranking what are the most important constraints to maintain probably would be a good option because I have yet to see consistent views regarding ranking constraints in terms of importance that we can use to drive MIP monetary policy tool development. BTW:  I voted to increase WBTC by 10-20M and lower or keep same SF.

Yeah hard to say what an extra 25% might do price wise. Given the current situation seems like a great idea though. One question on the above:     MakerMan:  WBTC SF down from 2-1.5% up DC at least 10M - maybe 20M   Why decrease the SF here since we are seeing pretty significant demand at the current rate? Seems like we would just be cutting the cost to borrow just for the sake of doing it.

Good question! We already have high demand so yeah probably keep the SF exactly the same until they won’t eat up the extra DC and then maybe lower it a little. I like that with some of these the protocol is getting some fees.  Given the really significant demand one could argue to raise the DC and raise the rate a little on this one.  I think what I wanted to see was a kind of set of rates that were pretty consistent across the board excepting some extra RPs on some. Some of the SF’s kind of don’t make sense from a RP perspective.  USDC-A at 4%, with ETH-A at 0% and wBTC in the middle at 2%…   Just doesn’t look consistent from a monetary policy perspective.  Is USDC actually more risky than wBTC at this point?

I agree on this. If we treat ETH and BTC as deserving the same Risk Premium (0% right now), USDC-A and WBTC should probably have the same stability fee unless we think Circle and BigGo deserve a different Centralization Premium.
The current demand for DAI is strong, and we should increase SF while increasing DC. If DC drops, SF should be reduced at the same time to stimulate an increase in DAI supply.

We may not have a consistent policy but we do have a consistent target. Ensure the peg and optimize DAI supply while maximizing revenue/reserves. What do we need to ensure the peg? Not a simple question but part of the answer now is to increase supply How de we do that? Reducing fees/New collaterals What happens if the fees are below the risk profile of the asset? It’s a trade off between the collateral and the peg, we choose the peg. Perhaps other options changes this trade off but sadly it’s all we have right now. If there is high demand for a collateral, should we increase the fee to capture more profit? As long as the supply is increasing helping support the peg definitely yes. We should optimize and another way to look at it is that is subsidizing eth 0% fees. If another black thursday were to happen I would want the biggest war chest we can have and that’s not going to happen at 0% rates

I do believe this is timely. In beginning of May WBTC was added to Maker with market cap of ~1100 BTC = ~$10mm and it was given a 10mm DAI debt ceiling. Besides the centralization risk, the two issues that were brought up at the time were low liquidity and the fact that the community was unsure of demand for WBTC outside of Maker. The two above issues have shown significant progress. Currently, there’s a market cap of around ~11000 WBTC = ~$100mm. Although a good part of this growth has been due to Maker, a large part of the demand has been outside of Maker. Additionally, there are around 5 new merchants being added to the WBTC ecosystem and this allows the ecosystem to scale liquidity much better with demand.

BTC has a high demand for DAI, I predict it should be more than twice that of ETH。

I’m against raising the WBTC DC. Anyone can sell their BTC and use ETH instead. We are building on the ETH chain and we should support hodling ETH. Not to mention that WBTC is a centralized coin and now we are approaching the point where one government decision could freeze 50% of our collateral (USDC+WBTC). @valo I tend to agree. We should let decentralized versions of BTC on the Ethereum blockchain grow in size.

WBTC is not required for liquidations, DAI is. If you meant selling the wbtc, then I’d say most keepers would just hedge in the far more liquid btc markets and then settle their wbtc more slowly. This could be a problem as keepers are not able to recycle capital as quickly with wbtc as they can with eth

Curve pools have quite a bit of liquidity for WBTC. This pool has $34m in reserves. Can swap for renbtc which can be unwrapped for bitcoin. With sbtc you can use the synthetix exchange and trade for susd or seth. https://www.curve.fi/sbtc

But we have to take a decision either to accept the risk and increase the ceiling or decrease the risk by putting the rate up. Currently the situation is no one can enter in it at any price.

Also i think we should begin the process to raise the DC even further potentially the RP as well. People are taking our product offering here so it doesn’t seem wise to stifle that growth. Potentially we could rope in @cyrus and @LongForWisdom  to avoid another 3 week turnaround on the DC increase. Update: On a second thought idk if I am pro-raising the ceiling ATM. With 50% of WBTC in our custody IDK if I personally would be comfortable with our exposure going much higher until more is minted. Which just makes me think the best course of action is to onboard renBTC.

I guess we have to agree here on what the cost of custodial risk. For USDC-A we are charging 4% (although i think this was mostly because of the wide gap between compound and maker borrowing rates), whereas for wbtc we are only charging 2% for custodial + price risk. Probably if we decide the usdc-a RP is correct we should raise the wbtc RP to ~6% and raise the eth RP to ~2%.

One thing I would say is that I (and probably @cyrus) would much rather the community made the effort to setup the signals anyway (even if we end up expediting the results.) Anytime we need to do something unscheduled, knowing there is some level of support (for example from a signal thread) makes the decision a lot less stressful for everyone. If the community continues to rely on Cyrus and myself to do expedited governance actions, at some point we’re inevitably going to misinterpret where the community stands on an issue and annoy everyone. (I’d also suggest starting a new thread to discuss this.)
Exactly, we could take WBTC minting as an informal indicator to increase the DC and increase the RP, perhaps 1%? Meanwhile start diversifying our btc exposure

I think that is sort of ignoring the problem here fwiw. My point here is that the community signaling process is SLOW. Read:     hongbiao_li:  The WBTC debt reached the upper limit a month ago, and we only started to increase the DC today, which made us miss some users.   If roping in governance is the only way to get a < 3 week turnaround then we should expect people to keep doing it. There needs to be a streamlined process and right now you guys are it. For better or for worse.

So start a signal to increase the debt ceiling and include a poll to do it as an emergency action. If the community agree that a signal should bypass the usual process as an emergency action, then we can bypass the usual process. It’s not something we can default to, though. If you have a suggestion on how to speed up the process while ensuring that there is still sufficient time for discussion, I’m happy to hear it.

If anyone wants to start the signaling thread im supportive, but at the end of the day idk that I see it as something to do atm. Id refer people to my update above.     Andy_McCall:  Update: On a second thought idk if I am pro-raising the ceiling ATM. With 50% of WBTC in our custody IDK if I personally would be comfortable with our exposure going much higher until more is minted . Which just makes me think the best course of action is to onboard renBTC.
Thanks for clarifying.

It’s worth mentioning that renBTC helps WBTC vaults a great deal in events of liquidation. About 90% of renBTC is sitting in 2 Curve pools and a Balancer pool, allowing keepers to go from WBTC to renBTC and then to BTC. I’ve brought DeversiFi up multiple times before and I believe it to be the dark horse here and it gets ignored a bit. Because of the mapping with Bitfinex, DeversiFi can take on a lot of WBTC in exchange for USDT in such events.

Seems like the clear market signal here is that wBTC at 2% is a bargain and people are happy to shift their custodial risk to Maker for that fee. To me this says that we have significantly underpriced the risk involved with this asset and the stability fee needs to be raised.
I’d raise the WBTC premium to as high as possible and I’ll vote against the DC increase.

Ren does not actually use a multisig though. It uses an MPC algorithm to simulate the same properties of a multisig, but on a single private key. The consequence is, although it is still “N out of M”, these values are much bigger, and can be applied in multiple layers. Concretely, 2-out-of-2 signatures are used to custody funds, but each key is itself simulated into a multisig using the MPC algorithm. The first key is 34-out-of-100, where the signatories are selected from a permission-less pool of nodes (currently 1100+ in size). The second key is N-out-of-M (where N = M/3+1), where the signatories are voted in by the community, based upon their reputation and respective ecosystem sizes (for example, Curve is a member of this one of the participants in this signature, because their ecosystem is well-incentivised to behave based on their use of renBTC).

You are correct in saying that Ren does not use a multisig, however, you agree that the security model is almost identical to that of a multisig. You also state that funds are 2of2 custodied, where the first is an MPC system and the second is also an MPC system but without permissionless participation of the first. This setup indicates a few things to me:  In it’s current iteration, your team does not have sufficient faith in the security of the 1100 nodes operated by token holders. Likely due to you guys not believing the tokens are sufficiently circulated yet. While the funds cannot be stolen by a “multisig”, is it fair to say they could be burned by the 2nd MPC run by trusted community members?  I believe REN is a great project and renBTC should be included as collateral but I also think it is quite high risk and early stage (and not necessarily better than wBTC across the board). Do you find the following summary of the renBTC’s risk model fair:  renBTC assumes that it is sufficiently difficult for pseudoanonymous nodes to collude and achieve 1/3 quorum. renBTC assumes that colluding pseudononymous and community actors will lose more in REN value or reputational value than they gain in collateral stolen value  If either of these conditions hold then the system is safe (ignoring the scenario where community actors collude to burn but not steal), otherwise, funds are at risk.

I would like more information from the liquidation experts on what would actually happen in a black swan event where the price of BTC and ETH drop a certain percentage much like what happened on Black Thursday. Looking at the @Vishesh maker vault data - http://makervaults.descipher.io/ If BTC drops 26% or ~$3000 from $11,650 to ~$8,600, 28 million of WBTC vault collateral is liquidated. If BTC drops another 5% to ~$8,200, an additional 10 million of WBTC vault collateral is liquidated. If ETH drops 33% or $120 from $358 to $238, 41 million of ETH vault collateral is liquidated. Could the ecosystem handle these liquidations? Don’t get me wrong, I want to see the WBTC debt ceiling raised immediately, but it would be good to get the risk work done first.

I’m not sure if the ecosystem could handle these liquidations, but I do want to point out that the vault data is a snapshot in time. Vault owners regularly adjust their collaterlization ratios during increased market volatility. With that being said, if Bitcoin’s price were to drop $3,000, the liquidation price of many large vaults could adjust as well.

During a liquidation event, liquidators are able to purchase collateral, presumably at a discount, using DAI. This means it is critical that:  Liquidators are able to access DAI to use to purchase collateral with. Liquidators are able to hedge the price exposure they gain by purchasing collateral. Liquidators can recycle capital or have sufficient capital to cover all auctions.  For wBTC, the main concern in my eyes is point 3. For 1 we now have the USDC-B vault. For 2 we have extremely liquid BTCUSD markets in crypto. But for 3 I’d like to know how long it takes to turn wBTC into BTC in order to settle a hedge put on in a BTCUSD market.

it is also worth noting that the current iteration of the liquidation / auction system is VERY new (released in the past week), so I don’t think that anyone can say that they know for certain how just our liquidation tech would perform under these kinds of circumstances. Outside of the tech concerns, 26% drop in BTC price would be hugely detrimental to the loan portfolio as a whole. You’d likely see ETH plummet right with it, so really ends up becoming how much demand is there going to be from the keepers of the world to buy this depressed collateral and at what price would they take it. Do keepers have the capital reserves required to soak up ~60M DAI worth of bad debt? No idea. That said as long as there is enough liquidity in the keeper pool to soak up maybe half that amount I think the system would be “fine.” Although MKR holders would end up eating a big bill in that circumstance. Anything more than that and we would be into real uncharted territory. As dire as all of that sounds my stance on this is that BTC price risk is no worse than ETH price risk given that they are so correlated, so in my view as long as the desire is to grow the loan portfolio as much as we can, accepting more WBTC is no better or worse than accepting ETH. This view makes the price risk arguments end up being a little moot. The only material thing here IMO is whether or not you want to accept the custodian risk which is certainly a concern.

Thanks @Andy_McCall - do you know if the new auction system has the ability to regulate the rate at which vaults are liquidated? This would help reduce the risk of item 3 above that @OliverNChalk pointed out.

There is the circuit breaker that is in place that i believe stops all liquidations regardless of collateral type, but i don’t think the v1.1 liquidations have any sort of throttling mechanisms in terms of amount of collateral liquidated per unit time.
